dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy Garland’s “Get Happy” plays as the camera surfs thro the streets of Laguna Beach. It’s another perfect day. Su shines through the palm trees, birds chirp and the ocean washes up on the shore in the distance. We focus in on a VOLVO SUV as it turns into a parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEN, poised and put together, pulls her SUV into a parkin spot. She checks her eye make-up in the mirror. It’s smud from crying. She wipes the runny mascara off her cheek, p on some lipstick and gathers herself. INT. JEN’S VOLVO - CONTINUOUS The song “Paralyzed” by the HARDCORE GERMAN DEATH METAL b Caliban blasts on Jen’s stereo.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT OF MY HEAD.
dialogues.text: Jen, unfazed by the music, blots her lipstick on a napkin She takes a deep breath, grabs her purse and exits the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen walks up a beautifully gardened pathway to a charming bluffside GAZEBO. A sign attached to the gazebo’s entranc reads “Friends of Heaven.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen, uncomfortable, heads to an underwhelming snack table WORN-OUT-LOOKING PEOPLE gather. She pours herself coffee, takes a sip and spits it right back into her cup. JUDY approaches, smiling. She exudes warmth, a touch of hippy just a sliver of sadness.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (to Judy) Skip the coffee. It’s awful.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I made it.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m kidding. It’s terrible. (extends her hand) I’m Judy.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (hesitantly shakes it Jen.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Beautiful day, right?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (over it) It always is.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I love your blouse. It’s a good color for you. Most people don’t know their palate. They’11 wear a spring when they’re a fall but you know you’re a winter and that’s huge.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (playful) You come to this group often?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: My first time.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Me too. (then) I’11 leave you alone. (then) But sorry, hope this isn’t weird... you do real estate, right? I feel like I’ve seen your picture on like a bus bench. You and a cute gay guy.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s me. And Christopher, who does not think he looks gay in that picture.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn’t mean it in a bad way. Gay is a beautiful thing. Who doesn’t want a gay real estate agent?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Which bench did you see?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: The one where you’re like -- Judy puts her hands on her hips and fake smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, I meant, I guess I meant where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Sorry. Newport.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (surprised) You live in Newport?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don’t think I belong there either.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Not belonging there is a good thing. Jen grabs a business card from her purse and hands it to Judy. JEN (CONT’D) If you ever need a realtor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I might, thank you. Sorry, I hope this isn’t weird but... can I... hug you?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: -No.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I don’t really like to be touched.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 4, 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Sorry, I’m just, I’ma hugger and I thought you kinda look like you need a hug.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Well, you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m really fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen, in an ANGRY RAGE, throws a decorative side table at CHRISTOPHER, her church-going-gay real estate partner. He lunges out of the way, as the table shatters a sliding gl door. Their clients, a RICH ORANGE COUNTY COUPLE, look on fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen and Judy sit in a circle of chairs with PASTOR WAYNE, kind, older man with a bad toupee, KYLE, a middle-aged feelings-eater, YOLANDA, a religious older black woman, WENDY, a sweet lesbian, and LINDA, dead inside.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Looks like we have some new people today. He looks at Jen, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Alright. Well, welcome to Friends of Heaven. I’m Pastor Wayne. As some of you know, I like to start out our grief circle by talking about a loss I lived through, that got me into this work. Nice haircut, Wendy. Wendy smiles.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 5. 3/20/18 PASTOR WAYNE (CONT’D) My aunt fell down a flight of stairs and cracked her head open and bled out as her five-year-old son watched. And I was the one who asked her to get me a soda from the basement. So, I live with that. And that’s a little something about me.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: I appreciate that. Is there a loss you’ve had that you’d like to share with us today?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I... um, I lost my fiancé eight weeks ago. (tearing up) I’m Judy.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hi, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Hi. (beat) It was really sudden. One minute we were eating dinner and then the next, he was gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy, in a pretty summer dress, is doubled over, crying n to a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (through messy tears) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on Judy.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 6. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: Heart attack?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (nods) He was forty-nine.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (sympathetic) That sucks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (through messy tears) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Thank you for sharing that. Does anyone else new want to share about a loss they’re living with? Everyone looks at Jen.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: At your own pace.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Jen) I didn’t talk my first week either.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: So, last week we started talking about the “F word.” Jen and Judy exchange a confused look.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgiveness. Forgiveness can be very difficult, and it can take time, even a lifetime, but it’s a way through. Sometimes we need to forgive the person who passed, a doctor maybe, an EMT who arrived too late, God, maybe ourselves. But, no matter what the circumstances, everyone is deserving of forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You really think that?

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Jesus thought that.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 7. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: --How do you forgive someone for hitting your husband with their car, then driving away and leaving him to bleed to death on the side of a road? The room goes quiet as everyone looks at Jen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes still on Jen.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, that’s it. I don’t really want to get into it, I just -- someone else can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group gives Judy supportive looks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (choking back tears) It feels like such a deep ache. Not just for how much I miss him, but for the things I won’t even get to miss. We were three months away from our wedding. I have my dream dress hanging in my closet. It’s a 1950’s vintage princess scoop neck.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh, pretty.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it fits really well.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: I miss my husband so much sometimes I think I’1ll be sick.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: These things take time.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: It’s been eighteen years.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (to herself) Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Why do people have to die?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: And why do we have to forgive? (then, re: Jen) She’s supposed to forgive a hit and run driver? I’m supposed to forgive cancer? Cancer left my daughter without a mom. Fuck cancer. Cancer's a big fat crooked dick. Sorry, Pastor.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Alright.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: (starts to cry When does the pain go away?

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: It will.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Or it won’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Is this -- I’m sorry -- is this supposed to be making me feel better? Because this is -- you’re all very sad. And I’m really truly sorry, but I have enough of my own misery. I don’t have room for anyone else’s.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Of course, I know it can feel that way. It's okay that you're feeling whatever you're feeling: sad, angry, defensive --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m not defensive, I’m just -- I’m tired.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m tired too.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: (to Jen) Can you tell us about that?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 9. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I just haven’t been sleeping. I was never a good sleeper, but since Ted died, I don’t sleep. Not naturally, anyway. And I don’t want to take pills, I’m not apills person. I have two kids, two boys who need me and I’m not gonna be one of those Xanax Ambien Zombie Moms. Linda, dead-faced, gives Jen a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Nights are really hard.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Mornings suck too.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, they’re okay for like two seconds --

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: -- But then you remember.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: And it’s like you’re living ina recurring nightmare -- but you can’t wake up, because you are awake.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (re: Judy) She gets it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I get it. Jen and Judy share her a small smile. Two peas in a sad, tired pod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is dispersing. As Jen heads out, Judy stops her

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m up all night. Judy hands Jen a small piece of paper.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 10. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feel free to call me and we can not sleep together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen enters a beach chic office as Christopher, in a neck brace, whips around in his desk chair.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (startled) Jesus in heaven! Jen, you know I’m still a little on edge.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I told you I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yes, I got the orchid, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I went. To that grief group.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You did? Pastor Wayne there?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: He was.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: He ask about me? J.K. I’m glad you went. Did it help?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m completely better.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Is sarcasm one of the stages of grief?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s right after throwing shit at your business partner when they say “maybe you just should be grateful for the time you had with your dead husband.”

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s a real stage. (off her look) Jen, I was just trying to help you. And, frankly, after thirteen years, it’s hurtful you think of me as just your “business partner.”  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 11. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: You know what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You know I love you, right? You’re like family to me.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: You don’t like your family.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You know what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Any word from Vista Glen? The repair estimate come in?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Eighty-five-hundred. The doors were custom.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Fine, we’ll make it up when we sell it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: We won’t actually. They dropped us. And so did Valley Drive. When they heard what happened at Vista Glen.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Listen, Jenny, you’ve been through a tragic loss, just a total nightmare. Maybe you should think about taking some time off --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (sharp) I don’t want to take any fucking time off!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (a little scared) Okay!

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Sorry. (then) I’1l find us a new listing. A good one. I promise. I’ll make it up to you.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 12. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. You do that. (beat) And you let me know if there’s anything I can do for you and the kids.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Wanna come over for dinner Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Can’t this weekend. The boys and I are in Palm Springs. But let’s raincheck that for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pastel-painted rec room filled with ELDERLY PEOPLE play cards, reading, and staring out the window. Judy approach ABE, 86, sharper than the rest.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Abe, the nurse says you’re not taking your statins. She asked me to see what’s going on. Not that I need an excuse to talk to the hottest guy in here.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: That’s not saying a lot. If you consider the other contestants.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Why aren’t you taking them?

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: I don’t need ‘em. It’s not a concern. I survived the Holocaust, high cholesterol doesn’t really move the needle for me. What I really need is some reefer.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What? (sotto) You already went through what I gave you?

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: What else am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You could be doing a lot. There’s a bridge tournament on Tuesdays, I lead a chair yoga class every morning --  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 13. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: I don’t have the knees for yoga.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s very low impact.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: I just don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1ll get some pot for you.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (presents pill cup) But you have to take this for me. Because I love you. And I can’t deal with losing anyone else right now... She starts to choke backs tears.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, now. Judy, don’t cry, come on. Don’t cry. I’1l take ‘em. I’11 take ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... I’m just, I think I’m feeling a little alone right now.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: Right now, of course. I understand. (takes her hand) You know, after Lydia died, I never thought I'd meet anyone or love anyone again. But I was wrong, right?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: Because then I met Diane.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Right, you’re right. (beat) But then Diane died.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: That’s true.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 14. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S HOUSE - EVENING Jen’s at the door. KAREN, an uptight Orange County mom, h her a casserole.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: So, you just heat it up at three hundred and leave it in for thirty-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Karen. But you really don’t have to keep --

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It’s my take on Mexican lasagna.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (curt) Great.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. We just don’t want you to think you’re alone. Jeff and I are here for you. If you ever want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Just can’t imagine what you’re going through.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Well, it’s like if Jeff was hit by acar and died. Suddenly. And violently.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Right. (then, re: casserole) Well, you get that dish back to me whenever you can. No rush -- Jen shuts the door in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen eats the casserole with her sons, CHARLIE, 14, all ed and HENRY, 9, all soft.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why are there raisins in this?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 15. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I honestly don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I like it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sick of other people’s food.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I miss Dad’s cooking.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s so not fair.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Which part?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why did our dad have to die? Why didn’t Tyler’s dad die? Rick. That guy’s a douche. Jen can’t help but nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I like Rick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHITE GUY IN A TURBAN hands Judy a take-out container.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE GUY
dialogues.text: Namaste.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Glen. INT. HENRY’S BEDROOM - EVENING Jen tucks Henry in. She turns off a lamp, and switches on night light.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: You have to wait ‘til I’m asleep. All the way asleep.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 16. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I know, Boop.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Mommy, I don’t want to go to school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I want to go to work with you.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I know, Hen, but we can’t do that anymore. It’s been three months. We gotta go back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: (getting worked up) But I want to be with you.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I know. I know you do. (then) You know, honey, what happened to your dad was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: As far as we know.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (yelling) Charlie, please! (then, to Henry) What happened to your dad was a freak accident.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: And nothing like that is going to happen to me. I’m going to be fine. I promise. So, you don’t have to worry, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I’m not worried something is going to happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (not buying it) No? Then what are you worried about?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 17. 3/20/18 Henry takes Jen’s hand in his as he closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: I just don’t want you to be alone. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - A LITTLE LATER Jen ugly sobs under the covers. It’s a big master bedroom she seems small in it. She gets up, muffling her crying w a pillow, as she crosses into the bathroom. She pees, sti crying into a pillow. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - A LITTLE LATER We see Jen go through her nightly rituals: -She pumps full speed on the Elliptical, drenched in swea -She finishes a work e-mail on her laptop. She types: “,..perfect time to list your house. It’s a seller’s mark -She watches an old movie on TV, dressed in her husband's pajamas, her wet hair in a towel. -She looks at her husband’s side of the bed. -She stares at the ceiling fan spinning. Her bedside cloc reads: 12:06. Then, at a loss, she takes out Judy's number.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: INT. JUDY’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME Judy, wide awake, lays in the dark, watching Oprah’s SuperSoul Sunday. Her phone rings, she answers and we intercut the following conversation:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Hi... it's Jen... from the grief group.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (perks up) Hiiii.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I don't know why I called you.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 18. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s okay, I said you could.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Is it too late?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m totally asleep.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Me too. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You in bed?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (suggestively) What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (taken aback) What?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: My husband's sweatpants and a T-shirt he got for running a 5K for psoriasis.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Slower.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: You're a weird person, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (then) Did your husband like running? Or did he just hate psoriasis? Jen goes silent. JUDY (CONT’D) Sorry, you don’t have to talk about him if you don’t want to.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 19. 3/20/18 A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: He liked running. But he came to it later. He started when he was forty -- the Couch To 5K app.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What made him start?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: He was getting doughy.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, guys get that middle aged man puff.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Oh, he was getting a full on beer belly. But he also getting beer neck.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Beer neck!

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I got on him a little, ‘cause he was lazy, and I was physically repulsed by him --

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You weren’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (she was) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: So... he started running. Got really into it. He was training for the Maui marathon. I was proud of him. He was in the best shape of his life when the car hit him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then, listening) Are you eating something?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 20. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s a donut. (takes a bite) And honestly, I feel really good about it. INT. JEN’S KITCHEN / JUDY’S BEDROOM - A LITTLE LATER Jen eats an Entenmann’s donut at her kitchen island, stil the phone with Judy. The microwave clock reads 12:47.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: ..-.Ted was always a gifted writer, even then. And he was the only guy in my dorm who listened to Ani DiFranco.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I love Ani.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: She’s not for me, but I liked that about him. (beat, then) I haven’t really talked about him much since he died.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We can stop. I don’t mean to pry --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No... it’s, um, it’s nice. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM / JUDY’S BEDROOM - LATER Jen lays sideways across her bed, still on the phone with Judy. Her bedside clock reads 2:38.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Did you get it? Judy looks at a photo on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, that’s my other husband.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh, you have another one? You’re fine.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if something happens to him...  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 21. 3/20/18 They laugh. JEN (CONT’D) It feels weird to be laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I think it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: When do you think it’s okay to masturbate again? (then, off Jen’s silence) Sorry, I don’t have any one else to ask.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, yeah, I don’t know the answer to that. (then) Not now? I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I'll google it. Jen yawns. JUDY (CONT’D) (re: yawn) I heard that. You should ride that wave and go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, I wanna see a photo of Steve.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’d have to look. Jen’s phone dings. Judy sent ten photos. JUDY (CONT’D) Found some. Jen scrolls through the pics. Steve is a cute, clean cut, well-dressed man. Jen stops on a photo of Steve standing front of a beautiful, expensive looking Newport Beach hou

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Is that your house?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot"

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Wow. (a beat, then) He’s not what I pictured.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Steve was a real normal. Judy gets choked up.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Handsome though.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I thought he had a JFK Jr. vibe when we met.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Oh, JFK Jr. So hot.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: So hot.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Then so sad.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: So sad. That death seemed like really? That family hasn’t been through enough?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Seriously. And you gotta take down the wife and the sister? Jen yawns again.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You’ re tired.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I think I am. You’re not?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Not really, but I’11 let you go.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No. (beat) Would you mind... would you mind just waiting ‘til I fall asleep?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. 22. 3/20/18  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 23. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Like all the way asleep.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Should I keep talk --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, because then I won’t be able to fall asleep.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Right. Judy stays on the phone, as Jen drifts off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As “Don’t Worry Baby” by The Beach Boys plays, we see: INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - MORNING -Jen wakes up with her phone next to her on the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Jen drives, sizing up different houses. -Jen approaches an OLDER MAN watering his giant lawn. She hands him her card. INT. JUDY’S NEWPORT BEACH HOUSE - DAY -Judy walks out of a huge walk-in closet, smelling one of fiancé’s shirts. She lays down on the bed and spoons it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Judy sits on a bench, alone, eating a salad. A YOUNG MOT pushing an ADORABLE BABY in a stroller, sits beside her. makes a silly face at the baby, and it smiles. The young mother looks at Judy, a little weirded out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Judy buys a bunch of weed and a can of peanuts.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 24, 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Jen drives, checking out every car parked on the street. -Jen pulls over, gets out and walks up to a car with aden front bumper. She writes down the license plate number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Judy nonchalantly hands Abe a can of peanuts. He opens t lid, peaks inside and smiles. END MONTAGE. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM / JUDY’S BEDROOM - A FEW NIGHTS LATER Jen lies in bed, sipping a glass of wine, on the phone wi Judy, who lights incense on a small table decorated with crystals, feathers and a deck of Affirmation Cards. Her T flickers in the background.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Oh my god, yes!

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Right? If I knew it was over, I would start smoking immediately.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Immediately. Smoking is the greatest thing that slowly kills you.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: The greatest. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Ooo, Facts of Life is on.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: What channel?
Jen grabs the remote and finds the channel.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I loved this show.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Loved it.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 25. 3/20/18 They watch for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: It’s not holding up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No. (then) Wait. I don’t remember. How small was this school? Was it just the five of them?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, they live in a dorm together and they’re friends. These very different girls who would never be friends. Jen takes a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JUDY’S BEDROOM / JEN’S BEDROOM - A FEW NIGHTS LATER CLOSE ON Judy as she takes a sip of wine. We WIDEN TO REV she’s now in a fresh pair of pajamas. We intercut with Je who’s in another pair of her husband’s pajamas. They watc different episode of “Facts of Life.”

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (re: Facts of Life) How did I not know this was on every night? More importantly, why are the other girls fifteen but Tootie is like nine?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) I don’t know. But has anyone ever told you you’re kind of a Blair?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: What?! Fuck you. I’m a Jo.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You sure? Cause I’ve known you for like two weeks, so I feel like I would know.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m a Jo!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Okay!  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 26. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Why? Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m a Tootie. It’s layered. How are you a Jo?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m tough. I’m from Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Brooklyn? How did I not know that? You don’t sound like you’re from Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I used to have an accent.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What’d you sound like?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Like someone with a Brooklyn accent.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Like how?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (reluctantly does Brooklyn accent) Like dis.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) That’s fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (laughs) I hate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy enters with two Starbucks coffees and hands one to J Jen smiles. They take their seats next to each other in t circle as Pastor Wayne starts the group. INT. HENRY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Jen lays wide awake next to Henry. She checks to make sur he’s asleep. She pokes him a little. He doesn’t budge. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - NEXT NIGHT Jen gets into bed and dials her phone.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 27. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S FOYER - A LITTLE LATER Judy stands at the door holding a bottle of wine in one h She pulls her other arm from behind her back to reveal a second bottle of wine. EXT. JEN’S BACKYARD - A LITTLE LATER Jen and Judy sit at the edge of the pool, drinking wine, their feet dangling in the water. It’s a bougie backyard, kind with an outdoor couch and a guesthouse.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Oh wow.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Christopher thinks he means well but he just consistently says the exact wrong thing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: So you had to throw a decorative end table at him?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. And then he gave me an ultimatum -- grief group or anger management. And I’m very attached to my anger.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I like your anger. I admire it.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: That's because you haven't been on the receiving end of it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I mean, there may be a healthier way you can channel it. Like meditation or --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You didn’t let me finish. Or murder.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I meditate. In my own way.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 28. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S VOLVO - MOMENTS LATER Jen and Judy sit in the car as Caliban’s “Paralyzed” blas Jen screams along to every word.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT OF MY HEAD.
dialogues.text: Judy is stunned, a little scared and kind of delighted. INT. JEN’S VOLVO - LATER Jen and Judy speed down Coast Highway, still listening to Caliban. Judy is trying, and failing, to get into the mus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy watches as Jen inspects a car with a dent in the fro bumper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Do you do this a lot?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, just every time I see a car witha person-sized dent in the front bumper.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (trying not to judge) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: The cops keep saying hit and runs are almost impossible to solve.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: But you feel like maybe you can find the person this way?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No. Jen writes down the license plate number.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 29. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S VOLVO - A LITTLE LATER Jen and Judy have the windows down, Caliban still blastin Out the window we see Jen and Christopher’s ad on a bus bench. Jen gives the ad the finger as she races past it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (shouting over the music I have an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen and Judy stand at the edge of a dramatic scenic cliff They both let out primal screams into the valley, as thei screams echo back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen and Judy sit on the sand.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I haven’t been to the beach at night in so long.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I love it. I really wanted to get aplace on the water. Just a condo. Just to hear the waves. But Steve wanted a salt water pool.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (re: ocean) What the fuck did he think this was?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) I know. Judy pulls out a joint and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s legal. Relax. She offers a puff to Jen.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, no -- I’m not a drugs person.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 30. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s not drugs, it’s a plant. It’1l help you sleep. Judy hands it to her. Jen reluctantly takes a puff, but s clearly comfortable handling a joint. JUDY (CONT’D) You totally smoke pot.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I did. With Ted, but it’s been years.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m happy to reacquaint you.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (re: the pot) Oh, you feel, like, immediately nice.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Hey. I hope this isn’t weird, but --

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That’s my line.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: But thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: For just, I don’t know, showing up in my life. Like a weird little pot fairy. And for not saying and doing the same stupid shit that everyone says and does that makes you feel more alone than you already do. And for not being repulsed by... my version of grief.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (touched) Thank you. For the same. It’s a really nice moment. A friendship sealed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow, one puff and you get all mushy.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 31. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. INT. JEN’S CAR / JUDY’S BEDROOM - NEXT NIGHT The phone rings through Jen’s Bluetooth. We intercut as J picks up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (putting her shoes on) Shall I head over?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, because I’m coming to you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: You've been coming to me for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You don’t even know where I live. Jen looks at her phone. She ZOOMS IN on the photo of Stev standing in front of their house. The house number is rig behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen pulls up to the matching house. She gets out, a box o donuts in hand. She knocks on the door. No answer. She kn again. The door opens. A man stands there in his robe. Je immediately recognizes him. It’s STEVE.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (floored) Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 32. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: You're... alive.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (confused) Yeah. It’s eleven-thirty. What is happening? Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: No, but I know Judy. Jen’s phone rings. She looks. It’s Judy calling.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Judy doesn’t live here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: She doesn’t?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Not since we broke up three months ago. And if you see her, tell her to stop coming here when I’m at work or I’mgonna change the locks.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m so -- I’m sorry to bother you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Goodnight. Steve starts to shut the door. Jen stops him. She takes something out of her purse and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s better if she doesn’t know where you live. (then) It’s a seller’s market. Steve looks at her business card and back at her, not kno what to make of any of it. INT. JUDY’S ROOM - SAME Judy paces and frantically calls Jen again. Her voicemail picks up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Jen, I can explain. (breaking down) Please call me. I’m so sorry. Please let me explain.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 33. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen charges in, just as the group takes their seats in th circle. Jen heads right for Judy.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Jen, please.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Why don’t you tell them what’s going on, Judy?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (to Wendy) I guess Kate and Allie are having trouble.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I can explain.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: What? That you’re an imposter? That you’re a fucking fraud? That you’ve been lying to me and to everyone pretending to be a fucking widow? Or a pre-widow, or whatever the fuck you wanna call it!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Just let me --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: It’s complicated --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: It’s not complicated! (to group) Her fiancé isn’t dead! Unless his fucking ghost answered the door last night! Because that would be complicated! But it’s not complicated! It’s pretty fucking simple -- he’s not fucking dead!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Jen, please!  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 34. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: What?! Do you get off pretending you’re going through what I’m going through? Was it like some kind of sick game you were playing with me? With all of us? Pretending like you lost someone? Making up a whole fucking story?! What the fuck is wrong with you?! You don’t belong in here! You didn’t lose him! He fucking broke up with you, probably because you're a fucking lunatic who lies about her fiancé being dead!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Jen, please -- settle down.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, let her talk.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I don’t want to let her fucking talk, Kyle!

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: I'd like to hear what Judy has to say.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Me too. Jen sits in a huff.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Well, that was powerful. Pastor Wayne shoots Jen a look.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Jen, I am so sorry. You have no idea. I’m sorry to all of you. I really am. I don’t know why -- I swear I wasn’t try to pull anything. Or hurt anyone. I never wanted to hurt anyone. But it’s true -- Steve is alive. He didn’t die three months ago, but I did lose him. Because he broke up with me.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Well, that’s not the fucking same!  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 35. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: He broke up with me because he desperately wanted to have kids, and I tried. A lot. For years. But I just kept having miscarriages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCH TO the previous flashback: Judy, in a pretty summer dress, is doubled over, crying next to a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (through messy tears) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Let’s get you to your room. As Judy stands up, we see blood on the front of her dress nurse puts an arm around Judy and escorts her down the ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is focused on Judy, except for Jen, who can’t br herself to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, honey.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t always sure if I wanted to be a mother, to be honest. But the first time I got pregnant, it was... I just never experienced a pure joy like that. I never felt so close to something. But I couldn’t... hold on to it. I kept trying. Kept wanting it to work... but something inside me just doesn’t. After the fifth one, Steve was done. He decided maybe if he found someone younger, or less broken inside... and none of that matters. I’m sorry I misrepresented myself. I should never have come here. (then) Jen, I’m so sorry I hurt you -- it’s the last thing I wanted to do. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 36. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (breaking down) I really cherish our friendship. I really do. I’m so sorry. Judy rushes out the door, in a trail of tears.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What a terrible story.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you believe it.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Me? What about her?

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: She’s in pain and I know you are too, but that doesn’t make it okay for you to attack someone like that.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (to Jen) Don’t you guys hang out all the time? How did you not know any of that? Did you ever ask her about her life?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: (defensive) Yeah --

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You didn’t need to expose her like that.

dialogues.speaker: YOLANDA
dialogues.text: You made her feel like she didn’t belong here. She has every right to sit in this circle. Poor girl’s had five miscarriages.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I really feel for her.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean in a lot of ways, her life is sadder than... a lot of ours.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: She lied!  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 37. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR WAYNE
dialogues.text: Jen. Everyone’s grief manifests in different ways. Judy lied. You flew into a terrifying rage. We’re all doing our best, and there’s no right way through, but you have got to start reconciling that anger inside of you. Jen seethes. PASTOR WAYNE (CONT’D) Don’t let it cause you more grief than you already have. A beat as this lands on her. INT. JEN’S CAR - AFTERNOON Jen turns on her engine and Caliban starts blaring. She punches the off button hard and starts to cry. INT. JUDY’S ROOM - NIGHT Judy, devastated, smokes a cigarette out the window. She her phone, to see if maybe it’s ringing. It reads: 12:06.

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - LATER Jen’s phone reads 12:06. She puts it down and turns her T on. We hear a scene from “The Facts of Life.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NURSE points Jen toward Judy, who is organizing a shelf board games. Judy looks at Jen, but can’t make eye contac

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: You could have just told me.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I didn’t. I don’t know why. I just didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Well, you have issues.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I got ‘em too.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 38. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You’ re allowed.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: So are you. I mean, it’s weird that you lied about Steve. It’s fucked up. But maybe it was easier to lie about that than tell the truth about the other stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I said you didn’t belong there.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: But I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: But you do. You’ve lost a lot too.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but people have miscarriages all the time. It’s not like actual --

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I think it is. Not if a Republican is asking, but -- you heard a heartbeat and you fell in love in that heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (choking up) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: The whole Steve story might have been made up but your grief is real.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: (a beat, as she gets overwhelmed with emotion) I should remove myself from here because this is where I work and I’m snotting on the carpet. As Judy heads out toward the hall, Abe approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: ABE
dialogues.text: You okay, doll? Judy manages a smile at Abe as she heads out of the rooma Jen follows.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 39. 3/20/18 INT. JUDY’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Jen looks around this small, depressing assisted living facility bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: This is where you were whenever we talked on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. They’ve been letting me stay here until I find a place. Rooms open up all the time.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming here. I didn’t think you'd ever talk to me again. You were so angry.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Told you you wouldn’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I did not. That was -- you were scary.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Sorry. (then, taking in the room) Look, this might be weird but -- my guest house is open. It was Ted’s office but it’s not like he’s using it. I can’t bring myself to set foot in there. But you’ re welcome to.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Welcome to what?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: To come and stay with us.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: That’s very generous, but you don’t have to take pity on me just because I’ma thirty-eight-year-old barren woman sleeping at an assisted living facility.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. Seriously, come.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 40. 3/20/18

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: It’ll be good. We can cut down our phone bills.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I thought you don’t have room for anyone else’s sadness.

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: I can try to make some.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (a beat) Can I hug you now?

dialogues.speaker: JEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but only because you look like you need it. Judy hugs Jen. They stay there a while. It’s warm and swe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen and Christopher hammer a FOR SALE sign into the lawn house. The front door opens. Steve walks out as we WIDEN REVEAL it’s his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy opens the garage door to her storage facility. She f on the lights and we see the side of a vintage Volkswagen shelves filled with boxes and lamps, etc. She grabs a suitcase from a shelf, pulls some clothes fro box and packs them into her suitcase. She opens the trunk the car and grabs some sneakers and a pair of boots. She shuts the trunk and walks to the front of the car. Sh looks at it and takes a breath. As she stands there, we s PAN OUT to see that she’s looking at a big PERSON-SIZED D in her front bumper. She turns off the light and pulls th garage door down, as Judy Garland’s “Get Happy” begins to play. And we... FADE TO BLACK.
